Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Bureaucratic Decisionmaking Concerning Families and Social Services

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bureaucratic intermediaries sometimes turn to the state to mobilize legal action on behalf of other people in a non-criminal context. This asks how and under what conditions, state workers decide to go to the legal system instead of the social service system in their casework? Based on in-depth interviews with state workers in multiple locales, this study examines how workers decide to guide families through state processes. The research design pays particular attention to how decisions are made in the context of tools designed to guide action in casework.
This work brings together the concept of legal mobilization and concepts concerning the significance of quantification in state decisionmaking, the process by which numbers come to define outcomes and determine policy in order to produce new knowledge about socio-legal decision-making. This research seeks to inform policy and practice and more broadly examines the policy implications of protocols that rely on actuarial risk models to standardize complex decisions and their outcomes. Research in this area has the potential to generate findings that will be of interest to scholars across a wide range of disciplines by connecting work on law and society, intervention research, social service systems, and the use of actuarial risk models to one another. Understanding the meaning-making process for these decisions is critical for clarifying how important policy debates about the utility of different approaches to social problems play out on the ground.

Because this project will be working with state decisionmakers, it will inform policy by returning the outcomes of the research to policymakers and caseworkers. In addition, it will contribute to training in social science methods for both undergraduates and a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There has been little scholarship that examines the ways in which front-line social service workers turn to the state to mobilize legal action on behalf of other people in a non-criminal context Seeking to address this gap, this research asks: How, and under what conditions, do child welfare workers make decisions to utilize the legal system over the social service system in their casework? In particular, decisions about legal mobilization are examined in the context of Structured Decision Making (SDM) tools designed to guide action in child welfare cases.  The goal of this work is to produce new knowledge about socio-legal decision-making, bringing together theories of legal mobilization with theories of quantification (the process by which numbers on a decision-tool come to define outcomes and determine policy). This research is based on interviews with 66 child welfare workers, informal observations of work in child welfare offices and close readings of primary documents in two states.

Moving discussions about legal mobilization beyond a grievance- or rights-based framework, this research elucidates the conditions under which street level bureaucrats decide when legal remedies are the appropriate response to child welfare problems. Further, this work identifies areas where opportunities to pursue legal interventions are avoided. Understanding the meaning-making process for these decisions is critical for clarifying how important policy debates about the utility of punitive versus rehabilitative approaches to social problems play out on the ground, particularly in the context of efforts to quantify and standardize these kinds of decisions.

I found that the extent to which standardization enters in to the decision-making process to determine legal intervention over the social service system varies by both organizational policy and worker. One state in my study, which I refer to as Tight State, mandated the use of the SDM and then tied key case decision-steps to scores on the SDM tool. Functionally, this meant the content of the SDM determined which families with substantiated neglect charges received legal interventions over social service interventions. Risk factors became a proxy for case severity and families with more risk factors, no matter the circumstances of the charge, received legal interventions in the form of protective supervision, removal of the child(ren) from the home and/or the termination of parental rights. The other state had a more flexible policy in relationship to the SDM, encouraging workers to use it to inform decision-making. In this state, which I termed Loose State, worker and supervisor decision-making and assessment were the determining factors for when legal interventions were employed over the social service system. The majority of workers and supervisors interviewed for this research in Loose State reported that the SDM was rarely, if ever, used as a basis for these decisions. 

The data also suggests that status characteristics intersect with organizational policy to structure how workers with the same job title respond to decision-making constraints. In Tight State, frontline workers whose status characteristics accord them more privilege reported flouting organizational rules to use the SDM, framing their decision-making as autonomous. The inverse is also true: CPS workers, whose status characteristics accord them lower social status, reported following the rules, experiencing their decision-making as restricted. These findings only held in an organizational context where standardized procedures were consequential for case trajectories. In Loose State, where standardized procedures were only ceremonially adopted, all workers experienced decision-making as unconstrained. These findings suggest that standardized decision-making tools do not inevitably resolve issues in decision-making that involve individual bias and subjectivity. 

These findings contribute to a larger debate about the utility or limitations of actuarial risk models for the reduction of bias in decision-making. These debates expand across legal and bureaucratic sectors as SDM tools have been introduced to aid decision-making in areas such as probation, sentencing, and the allocation of welfare benefits.
